div.p: A FRACTION IN THE ASSEMBLY: OR THE SYNOD IN ARMES Being a punctuall Relation of their ſet meeting, upon the 25. of Aprill in this preſent year of our Computation 1648 at a tavern in LONDON, where the purpoſes of thoſe reverend Fathers, were piouſly diſcovered by themſelves, in a mutuall conference by the ſtrength of a Dinner, and in the truth of wine: Their diſagreement, upon the queſtion: their falling out upon that; and how they were parted: with other mixtures of ſad and merry accidents being all paſſages very remarkeable: and curious obſervations, which the Author, as a generall well-wiſher, delivers heer to the worlds view- And he hopes ſatisfaction.
London Printed in the yeare, 1648.

q.l: AS once Olympian Jove: put Iuno by
And wiſe Minerva, Gave bold Mars the lye
Touching Troyes fate: when limping Uulcan ſcorus
To keepe heavens peace: and with ungratefull hornes
Butts at his freindly Rivall: Even ſuch odds
Tainted of late our ſublunary Gods
The ſacred Synod: which we mortalls call
The viols of Heavens wrath: O Troy: thy fall
Phaebus lamented: but in Englands dust
What hand writes pity, as if all were juſt
For patience has endurd: vengeance convince
Theſe of thir guilt and Charles that Godlike Prince
Let his white Truth prevaile: our ſtory cooles
Whoſe Lard ſeemes learning: and her fat rich fooles
Fed high with penſion dinners: Whoſe meere cloſe
Would burſt an Elephant: wele now ſpeake proſe,
Freinds what you ſee, beleeve, here is no lye
For when this chanc'd, the Authors ſelf was by

div.p:
PRay be not ſo angry Gentlemen; For that weighty misfortuns, whoſe Relations are to the publick, ſhould be knowne and conſidered, I deny not, ſeeing otherwiſe, how ſhall men declare their modeſt ſorrowings in matters neerely concerning them, or ſtudy their prevention, In the future, If they be ignorant of them: All this without the rack: or hanging by the great toe, with the head downeward like A dancer of the Ropes; or any other inquiſition torture, is confeſt freely: but this is it that I ſay. why ſhould one poore beaſt, be forſt to carry the burthen for a whole Kingdome: becauſe Mrs. ſuch a one:Shee is a Widdow. the Miſtris of the Taverne where this famous accident befell, with her whole family, have taken the Covenant, or Oaths of ſecreſie with theſe fathers, Confeſſors; to hide it from honeſt men, and ſo keepe the world in this, like other things in ignorance and infidelity; muſt I therefore, weepe my ſelfe into a Tranſformation: Be made a new river, as ſome have been before mee, as you may read in the Hiſtory of Miobe and others, in Ovids unerring Chronicle of his Metamorphoſis or be turnd into a frogge, for over-laughing my ſelfe, When J have a
mind to jeſt out my greifes: And all this becauſe, I only, had the fortune to be by — I ſay, there is no reaſon for it: no, there are more Aſſes in England beſides mee; let the matter be communicated: that every Lucius taking up his owne load, we may Jogge on like contented Market-Women, or Citizens wives to their Country houſes, fairely, and eaſily together: to what uſe ſerve Ambages amongſt friends, or why ſhould the Author with tedious Apologies Cuffe his ſtory into teares; becauſe he thruſts her back, and reſtraines her appearing, Even now, when by all viſible ſignes, ſhe hath A mighty mind to diſcover her ſelfe, take it therefore amongſt you, which in few words befell thus.

Vpon St. Markes day the 25. of Aprill the holines whereof is much envied by our Libertines of England, becauſe the ſuperſtitious Romans, obſerve it: halfe a dozen of our Synodicall Presbytery, peiced with juſt as many Independants, to make up the number, though of ſeverall colours, had a mind to condogge together.

Their meeting was at a Tavern in London, not a ſtrecht mile from the Old Exchange: which to cover the Nakedneſſe of a prime Damſell, the daughter of the houſe, and 'tis thought the loadſtone of that ſociety, ſhall for the preſent be nameleſſe.

After an humble Thankſgiving, for their arrivall at terra florida And that being ſuch, who by ſins of an unrecoverable miſcreancy, had tempted Heaven and Earth to deſtroy them, yet, the ſtones in the ſtreets, had not riſen up againſt them, either to breake their ſhins or their Necks in that their pilgrimage, concluding with an admiration, what providence that ſhould be that ſtill continu'd to protect them: Impenitent ſinners, they ſeated themſelves at a large round Table in a very faire Roome, and calling for fine Angelica which ſhall be her name here, after a briefe catachizing touching the ſtate of her virginity, and how the pulſe of her Concupiſcences did beate, whereof ſhe was much comforted to heare them tell her, all fleſh was guilty, ſhe received from them a bleſſing upon the lip, and they from her faire hand, the cup of Salutation, which that pretty Leman preſenting with wine and ſugar, they did her reaſon firſt, and then toſt it of freely one to another.

The joyning of two rounds together, engendred a diſcourſe delivered by a Doctor, in theſe words following, Brethren, we are heer condo ••• d together: As it were, to peck up a few Crummes of Conſolation
from this our mutuall enjoying one of another: in the plenty of the Creature, which we preſently expect, cal'd Meat, Wine, and Woemen: Renowned Subjects of the three firſt miracles: of theſe, we may feed till we burſt againe, for our purſes are full, the people our friends, And therefore the Houſe is likewiſe ours, while wee, whom the prophane of the Land call evill ſpirits, ſhall pleaſe to poſſeſſe it, But firſt, let us adviſe, and unſcruple our ſoules, leaſt any thing by chance, ſhould lie pinching us in that tender place, to the hurt of our preſent or future tranquillities: If any of you doubt, let him only queſtion, And be reſolved.

The motion was applauded, and thus trod upon the very heele by another, then are we quoth hee, the moſt miſerable of all men, if vox populi, carrie it's old credit, for that cals us the Incendiaries of the Nation: It ſaies, that weekly preaching have advanced Rebellion, Murder, Theft, Confuſion, and every evill worke: That we have brought contempt upon the Ghoſpell; That outwardly we conteſt as oppoſits, but ſecretly are agreed to nouriſh diviſions ſo long, like the Scotts, wee have gathered all buſineſſe into our diſcuſſing, that we may Judge and determine all things as chiefe moderators in matters of conſcience, and ſo, by degrees, ſteale the Soveraignty from King and People, and Plant it in our ſelves, the Clergy.

That neither wee, nor any Authorized by us, or lawfull Miniſters, becauſe we have forfited our calling by the double breach of thoſe two Oathes, Alleageance and Supremacy, which bound us to the King: who when he hath vanquiſht his toiles, will, they ſay, have us baited in Beares-skins, for playing to much the Foxes, as firſt to Drill him into a ſnare; And then ſet Doggs to worry him; not thoſe of a Generous kind, but mangy Mungrell Currs, cald Mildmay, Martin, Haman, and our ſelves, to whom they ſay, the Rogue laſt nam'd is only Turn-key; but we his Jailours, that may free him inſtantly, if we would but ſweeten the polluted Aire with pure Divinity. And from wounded hearts in penitentiall Pulpits, Ingeminate to Heaven, and men, our hearty ſorrowings for the high Crime, of our Soveraigne Lords unjuſt and violent Captivity, firſt cauſ'd by us, and now contrived by our connivences; in fine that all our faſting Prayers, are abhominations, becauſe our hands, they ſay are full of blood, neither can they heare our preaching, if they would, the Keyes of — keep ſuch a noiſe and ratling at our Girdles, all
which render us worſe then Baals Prieſts, or the 600. falſe Prophets that propheſied lies, and perſecuted the good men of God. Theſe Imputations that bold Vox Populi that preſumes to call Infinit thouſands of Men,The Chair mans Anſwer is all their Reſolutions. Women, and Children, nay, our owne Conſciences forſooth, for Witneſſes; he ſweares are no ſlanders, but bleeding truths, which ſo wounds my thoughts, and conſumes me in this very minute, that if your Sack here were not perfect Charinco, and the ſmell of our approaching Dinner reſtorative. I ſhould verily faint, and drop out of this Land of the living, and your Good Companies which would much greiue mee; to grope out uncertaine chances in another world, where tis ten to one, they ſerve not God after our manner; ſo, he ſipt off his Cup: was pledgd round, and thus ſatisfied by the Chaire-man.

Brother: we muſt ſute the behaviour of our Actions to the diſpoſition, or humor of their cauſes, which command ours at this time, to obſerve the poſture they now ſtand at: The people indeed exclaime, I ſay their cries are juſt, for by us, a Cloud is brought upon their Lawes, Liberties, Eſtates, nay perſons and all this by preaching, yet if this preſent momentary ill, conduces to their future good eternally: who ſhould theſe beetles thank, but us; Bitches have clogs: which we take off, to make them happy, if the ſilly Irrationall Cattell could but underſtand it, however, wee, that know it neceſſary are bound to practiſe it, for all their goods.

This Generation muſt ſuffer, for the ſins of thoſe paſt, and all that are to Come: The next by our endeavors, ſhall ſhine againe, with a Government ſo pure, and like heaven, that Angels ſhall ſeeme to be beguild, and love to live, at leaſt converſe with men as formerly, miſtake mee not, I meane with us heere in England: As for the Scotts, lately our Brethren, they are revolting poore Rogues, not worthy now, nor ever able to entertaine ſuch Gueſts: Let not theſe Nitts diſquiet you Mr.—to make you throw of the Dublet of your firſt reſolutions, If a rampant lowſe, or two, chance to trouble you, yet never unbutton for the matter, only tell me where they bite, ile helpe you to a remover ſtrait: come heers the Man, he was thank'd, pledgd, and ſhould have beene encountred with a reply, but as the word was ſallying out of the Reſpondents Lips: it was forſt to recoile by a whole file of Diſhes, which juſt then preſented upon them, The falling on was furious; they came ſuddenly to pell mell, And ſlaſht it without mercy.

You will aske paradventure, how I came to know all this; Ile tell you: A freind and I had agreed over night to meet at that very Taverne about 10 this morning, I kept my appointment, but my freind, as the faſhion is, failed me. I with a pinte of the pureſt before me, ſell a ſleepe, and was, it ſeemes, aſwell forgot by the houſe as my ſelfe, till the entrance of ſo many, and ſo neere me, with the ſhuffling of leggs and feet, ſtarted me in ſuch a fright, as had there been a chimney in the roome, I had certainely appeared at the top in a trice, and rather crept out that way, to ſhift for my ſelfe, then ſtood to the mercy of that Corporall, and his Squadron, for ſo I ſtrongly fancied theſe to be, that came to ſearch for malignants; of which outlaw'd family, my owne a King-heart told me verily, that I was a forlorne Brother; well, the Divill a Chimney was there, or a hole bigg enough, for Tom Thumbe to have hid himſelfe in; there was no remedy: I compoſed my fears the beſt J could, & ſetled my ſelfe, to liſten their ſitting diſcourſe, but eſpecially the ſight of them thorough a clift in the wainſcot, which only divided us, for t'was in the next a roome, ſo confirmed mee; that I drove care away to kill catts, and ſat prancking it upon my bench, as proudely, as St. George did upon his Beaſt, after he had killed the Dragon. Haveing given you this ſatisfaction, you are bound in conſcience to read on, and beleeve every word as followeth. Wee left them at dinner at the Tables end, ſat the fatt Miſtris of the Houſe, with a face appearing like a full Moone; by whome there ſhined her daughter, the faire Angelica, whoſe brightneſſe ſo ſtellified the roome, that thoſe elders could doe nothing elſe for a while, but drinke, and dart glances, feathered with wanton language at her, which ſhe retorted like another Venus, till her Tongue travel'd tantivie, and more then a Canterbury pace, and never Stopt till Mr. — Aſſaulted the Chaireman, whoſe place the Miſtris had borrowed very freſhly with ſome fragments of the firſt queſtion.

That although what he had uttered, was profound and undeniable, yet he was ſtill to ſeeke in two maine particulars; firſt of the Church differences which he ever held reall, till then, next touching the King: who being a Juſt: Good: Gratious: Mild: Mercifull: Magnanimous: Valiant: Pious: Wiſe Prince: in his opinion he deſerved Nobler uſage, and to be at liberty: The Doctor replied tis true; you have not flattered him in all this Glorious Charecter
for, tis his due; which is Attribute we owe to all: nay, the very Proverbe commands it for the Devill, yet to the King we muſt deny, this, under the Roſe here, weel give it him, amongſt our ſelves, but not publikely, for know: The government by Kings, and that wee aime at, which is to exalt the Church above it, are incompatible: If wee, ſubmitting to the equity you ſpeak of, which pleads hard for the King: ſhould replant him, you ſhould quickly perceive, what wild fruits that fooliſh Honeſty would bring forth: The awfull office of Biſhops would certainly floriſh again; Then pray what would become of vs: marry, Ile tell ye — if we ſcap'd hanging, even preſently be farted out of the Land, perhaps into that Jakes of Scotland, like ſome griping diſeaſe among the Gutts, or the wind Collick of the Kingdome: which they begin already to call Vs: No if we wiſh our owne utility, and the Churches Honor, we muſt heap Pelion upon Oſſa, raiſe ſuch a mount of ſcandals in the Kings way, as may bar his returne for ever, as being too high for all his patience or vindications, to climbe over, for example. Ther's Anthony Mildmay, a dear Proſelyt of ours. I can never call thee Rogue to mind, but me thinks, I wiſh my hands were ſtroaking his zealous heart, and chaſing it into new deſignes for us: This precious villaine, in a Letter to that Saint his Brother, ſome call him Serpent, becauſe he ſtings the King that cheriſht him: I confeſſe an offence that would damme him, were he not a Son of the Cauſe, and we his defenders, charge his Majeſty with ſeverall expreſsions in diſcourſe, which he cals Tyrannies, and Inveighing againſt him, with the extreameſt tartneſſe of a depraved Pen expoſes him to a malevolent cenſure, now we perceiving how the ſlave betraid his Maſter, by poiſoning the Innocence of his language, and meaning with wreſted conſtructions of his owne, which we well knew were falſe; Though we Admir'd the fellowes Impudency, yet we cheriſht his Information for the reaſon aforeſaid: and made ſpeciall uſes of it, to our owne eternall advantage, as we Imagine, and the Kings finall detriment: This which we hold far better, then an Act of oblivion or Indemnity, meets your feares of after queſtionings, and calls them Triviall.

Touching your ſecond doubt of our pretended Church differences Brethren, that the condition of ſtate Affaires is ſometimes ſuch as forces us, that manage them, to a deceptio viſus, A piece of Hocus, to benight mens Eyes at noone, and falſifie their object for their ruine.
We preſent ſomethings to the publick view juſt as they are, others not ſo, but as they ſeeme to be by our direction: we are not to ſentence any evill deſperate, whoſe remedy is in our ſelves, one famous trick of pure conveyance carried it, for we, the Synod firſt, and then the Parliament, pretended to divide, we preached, writ, diſgraced one another to the uttermoſt, which wanted no ſucceſſe, for the ſilly people, juſt as we imagin d, couzen'd with empty face of anger, ran preſently to ſides, and quickly wound the quarrell up to ſuch a height, as to avoid the cruſhing of a party when the weight ſhould fall, the continuance of an Army was reſolved upon, and ſo by their own miſ-priſions, counted neceſſary, which fitted our deſires juſt: This plot, thus wiſely laid, was likewiſe fortunate, for being thus ſeemingly oppoſite, we can open our pack by turnes, now the Presbyterian, then the Independent, and paſſe our wares at what price wee pleaſe upon the ſhallow world, which receives all our brocage, [as ſome diſparage it] it the ſecond hand, paying truly the deare rates of many thanks, and Reverence, not from any skill of their owne to judge, but as wee adorne it, with a gloſſe, and praiſe it.

Thus you ſee, thoſe our Sons of Weſtminſter, Obſerve the confeſſion. and London obey our contrivings: Our ſervants Fairfax, and Cromwell, like Eſau and Nimrod, ſmell ſtrongly of the field, and ſavor rank of the blood we command them to ſpill in hunting: and laſtly, wee, the Sages of Europe, and Englands Reverendiſſimoes, do keepe unity, as well as we can, and concord in a Golden band, I meane amongſt our ſelves being alwaies careful that neither of our parties outweigh the other, but both to lye ſo hard upon the King and his followers, that wee wonder, by what virtue or miracle they live.

This, I have told you, is the very heart of the affaire, which theſe dotterells of the Laity are not to ſearch into, but you the Sons of Eli, and my deare Iockey's muſt dive into the bottome of this or any other ſecret, wherein my art can pleaſure you.

After this Oration, he watered his dry pallate with a ſhower of White wine, to which he was very devoutly affected, and liquored his tongue to make it fruitfull for more flowers of Rhetoricke: That done, he demanded their opinion of what he had offered one, whoſe hands I marked were no unprofitable Servants to his ſtomack for in the interim of this long parley they had ſtored the Magazine of his belly with a moneths proviſion at leaſt, for feare of a famine from Kent and other Mutinous Counties, entreated the Chaireman
to excuſe them, foraſmuch as they had not been at leiſure to hearken to his Tale, which notwithſtanding, they were confident, was all true from the beginning, to the end of the laſt ſyllable: it being no more poſſible for him to erre, then the Popes holineſſe: To whoſe two Chaires, Infallibility, was equally annexed in aſſurance whereof, A black fellow, very like Mr. Marſhall, and ſure I think t'was he, taking up a weighty Boll, brim-full of Sack, offered to drink to any man in the Company that would pledge him, and be of his opinion; his challenge was received immediatly by another: what replied a third, that they ſay, ſeldome ſpake a true word, but in his Drink, is not this in the Devills name, a trick of the beaſt, to tell the people of a Cock and a Bull, and bind them to beleeve all the ſtories in Chawcer for Articles of Faith: pray what's this, but Implicita fides: the very bumbaſte father of Ignorance.

Brother, anſwerd the Chaire-man, That ignorance you deſpiſe ſo much, is, being rightly conceived, the true and ſober parent, not only of devotion towards Heaven, but of reverence to us: of which laſt Jewell it behoves us to have a more tender care, then of the other: Oracles were admir'd of old, becauſe, dark and ſtupendious, let a Riddle be once expounded, and every fool will tread upon it: I tell you againe, they muſt not be able to fathom our depth, tis ſufficient for them, to practiſe obedience, and for us, to embrace the example of our witty forefathers of the laſt Trent Councell, who when they added new, and ſtrange Articles, all contradiction to thoſe, was death, for a crime cald by them, Haereſy; and now by us Felony,Marke this Confeſſion which is true. eſpecially about the Ius Divinum, of our Presbyterian Government, never known till Calvin, by whom to ſpeak Truth, it was firſt broached, to get the man a name, and pleaſe the humorous pallate of the hare braind people.

Oderant ſi metuunt, Let them hate me ſo they feare me, was the Motto of a Tyrant,A Tyrannous Motto, allowd by the Synod. and yet in my judgement a ſentence more Divine, then any of Catoes: we muſt compell the vulgar Adoration to us, As the Divell does the Indians, Appeare in mild ſhapes to thoſe that love us, or ſubmit willingly, but be formidable to the reſt: you ſee how theſe Goats deſert us daily, & are not their revolts ſufficient to excuſe our cruelty, nay though we damn'd them after death — O how I am taken with your grave politicks, — & ſtand amazed at the profound myſterie of Propheſies: Machiavell crie I, was a ſprightly Gentleman, within Duce Ace, as wiſe as the Devill, if not wiſer: and Mother Shipton, As vaſt in her divinations, and as
Authentick an Author as any Sybill of them all: he drank to em, expecting an Applauſe—but it would not ſerve his turne, for being holyday as I told you, the Wine had kindled Bonefires in their braines, they valued neither him, nor his Chaire, and his language had ſo offended one, that he told him plainly he took him for Barabas, The Father of Inſurrections, not halfe ſo honeſt as a Brewers Clark, whoſe falſe Tally was alwaies ſworn to Cozen either the Maſter or his Cuſtomers, The Prolocutor, who to my thinking, rav'd, hearing this, and fearing worſe: cald all the Godly of both parties to ſide with him, if he were affronted further by that—ly—ing Raſcall, I think he would have ſaid, but the lye was returned into his Throat, before he could get out the reſt, and had almoſt choaked him, being rammed downe by three great Teeth of his owne, which were driven from their Palliſadoe, by an aſſault and battery.

He that gave this blow, I marked to be a man, whoſe face was ſo dyed in the Grain of Claret, that his plump Cheeks lookd for all the World, like a couple of flowing Wine-bagges, which in a moment were emptied, by a quick reſponſe from the Chaire-man, that with a caſt of his Office, hit him ſo home and hardily, as drew the Vintage in his face through the Spigot of his Noſe, and laid him flat upon the ground, like a bunch of Grapes new preſt.

This Patroclus had an Ajax, that beſtird him, who mowed downe the Chaireman at one ſwing with a pottle Pot, All hands were excerciſ'd in a moment, And by a rare method or keeping due time betwixt feet and fiſts, No man could take them for any other then profeſt dancers, that were notably skilfull in obſerving the Decorum of A brawle: The fray was ſilent, ſharp, and ſhort, for the houſe, cheifly Angelica, came running up, and parted them: They returnd to their ſeats: ſmil'd, at the Captiouſneſſe of great ſpirits, and cald for a Gallon of Nepenthe, a reconciling Drink, which they ſwallowed liberally, and were friends: The next Act was voiding the Table of all things, but a faire Cloth, a miraculous great Pie, plenty of wine to cleanſe their mouths, and Tobacco to foule them againe.

Their wits went now a wool-gathering, from Learning the Reverend wagges, would needs grow wanton with a peice of divination, What quoth one, if theſe Divells in Kent and Eſſex, ſhould get the better of our Saints in the Army, and ſo demand the Angells, in our two Houſes: And then thoſe ſpirits of the middle Region, the Londoners, in whoſe power I confeſſe it lies to diſpatch the buſineſſe in
few houres, ſhould deliver them up, What would then become of us all; — The chaire-man whoſe cuſtome it was to fall upon the kernell of the buſineſſe, for you ſee, he opened the ſhells as faſt, as any Weſell can crack nuts,New England replyed inſtantly, That all would prove indifferently well, for let it raine Doggs, and Cats, we, ſaid he, will recover our old ſanctified plantation, in deſpight of them, our ſublimer Saints: As Lenthall, Martin, Mildmay, and the reſt ſhall ſtep aſide into their ſeverall ports in Neighbour Nations, where they may unite the forces of Treaſure, and craft, of both which they have a large ſtock, as occaſion ſhall invite them, to toſſe new balls and make Engand wilde by the fire of another new Warre, This would be meritorious you know.

All in Good time, went on the Objector, If wee as you ſay, are able to cry, noli me tangere, when danger is ready to faſten, yet what will become of the frie, that have borne up our weake flights, upon the ſtrength, and reach of their long winged votes, and have all this while ſided with us, for theſe not being of the cabinet Counſell, will 'tis like, know nothing of the bogge, till they beſt fled in it.

They are good for nothing elſe, anſwered the Chaireman, but to be regarded, like Bills, and Bonds out of date, bundled up together for waſt papers, and reſerved only for poſterior uſes, — As they have voted with us, from the beginning without judgement, or againſt conſcience, ſo let them eene be hanged for us at laſt, Thats all I care.

Now you ſpeake of that, ſaid another, I am within an Inch of death with laughing: when I but think of that great Animall Pembrook, a fellow that appears amongſt the Lords in the upper houſe as the Devill did in Heaven, in a ſhuffling way, having indeede, no priviledge to be found in any place, where wit ſhould dwell, — Lord, what a Legacy of non-ſence, that Buffoone, will bequeath to the jeering Malignants when they are throug'd together to behold him, as he ſtands upon his degrees, for he hath lately beene at Oxford ye know, to preach his owne funerall ſermon at ſome ſelected Gallowes, for tis verily thought, that party, if they can but finger him, wil never honour ſuch a keckſhaw with the ſolemnity of a Scaffold, This Earle ſayes another, ſhould be alwayes thrown upon Tumults to pacifie them, for let him talke what he liſt to diſpleaſe the people, hees ſure, they cannot all knock out his braines, for theſe not only he, but all the reſt of the Peers, have delivered up to the ſingle cuſtody of Viſcount Say, a crafty Merchant that hath
ſealed them up from all mens uſes, but his owne, which makes their Honors ſit with empty Noddles, from whence they ſay, The higher Houſe is called an Hoſpitall of fools, and in ſubjection to the lower who for this very reaſon are to be their Guardians.

To this point they came; neither did theſe mountains of diſcourſe want their vallies, into which I will not trouble your diſcent, let it ſuffice us over looking many inferiour paſſages of the day to walke on ſtill keeping the higher ground till we arrive at Eleaven at night, which finiſhes the tragedy, and diſmiſſes the ſpectators.

Eleaven was the houre, till which time, though I had not eat a bit, yet I was not faſting: I confeſſe I fed not, like other men at the mouth, but by the eye, and eare aboundantly my noſe too, came in for a ſhare, which thruſting out of my Caſement, ſnuft up the hot ſteam of their broath and baKte meat, which nouriſht me exceedingly.

They were now high flown: Bacchus had crown'd all their temples with vermillion: his owne colours which are commonly purchaſed at a drunken rate, and looking thorough their owne eyes, now turn'd into multiplying Glaſſes, they ſtrongly fancied the huge pie before them to be full as big as London within the walls, this once falling into apprehenſions already diſtemperd: they ſtept into a higher degree of madneſſe,The wonderfull power of drinke, for an Independant ſtarted up and ſwore it was London it ſelfe, ſhewing the Armes, which ſaid he, you may behold blazon'd here upon one of her gates [he ment the Lid, where indeed they were Gallantly flouriſhed] and therefore I & my companions, embracing the opportunity, will now beſeige, and take it, for this we know is the maine deſigne of the Army, and all the well-affected party.

They grew from words to Action, and prepar'd in earneſt, ſome to deſtroy, others to defend it: The batterie was feirce, many a ſadd blow was diſcharged at the Pie that fell heavily upon one face or other, in a word, the Independent party prevaild, and the Chaire-man their Leader, beating downe the walls by force of Armes, the Cart of his ſtomack was the firſt that wheeld in, whereof himſelfe being Charioteer and Guide, he bore down all before him, and did a terrible execution with his owne hand.

The fortifications being quite leveld, profeſt friends fell to the plunder, like Enemies; never did poore Citizens ſuffer perſecution: and devouring with ſo much ſtrange patience, not a Groane, nor ſigh, it ſeemes remembring their faults againſt the King they ſilently confeſſed all theſe puniſhments juſt, well, extreames cannot laſt allwaies,
the Conqueror tyr'd with the labour of his own cruelty,This was don by the Cook-maid and A Drawer as themſelves told me ſince, when they perceivd I knew the matter. was willing to pardon the miſerable ſurviving relicks, which beginning to obſerve, they found them to be a Cluſter of Froggs, well doeſt and ſeaſoned: The men were amazd, and the Woemen ſcrietched like Owles to ſee the Metamorphoſis, and kneeling downe in a cold perplexity, they confeſt themſelves to thoſe Ghaſtly Fathers, in Termes Auricular, that as they never hoped to ſee Heaven, it was as ſweet a Woodcock pie, as ever kiſt the Lipps of a moderne Apoſtle: feare became fury: They gave all Pies they ſaid to the Divell, it was a City they look'd after, whoſe Inhabitants conquered by them, were firſt turnd into Frogs, by Art Magick, and now at the beſt, made but Woodcocks by the Sorſereſſes.

Two only of the Twelve perſwaded Peace, and in Scripture phraſes but could not be heard, for all ſpirit of meekneſſe bad forſaken them, yet being conſcious in themſelves, that they all had a ſmackering in Nicromancy, which they ſtudied more then divinity, they fell into a ſuſpition, that ſome one among them, had done this, to put a trick upon the reſt; but the Chaire-man, that ſnorted like Bucephalus, Alexanders horſe, in whom the fire of the firſt diſdaine was freſhly kindled, being before but rak'd up in a diſſembled pacification, would needs preſſe the buſineſſe in tempeſtuous language upon him, that had firſt ſtricken him, who likewiſe grudging at him with a fervent emulation thus retorted: that rather he himſelfe was the man, for who knew not him to be alwayes drawing lines of infernall communication, ſpending moſt of his time in familiar conference with a certaine Divel, whoſe name he had forgot, finally, he Affirm'd him to be one that ſurmounted Fauſtus in Magick, and could make babies of thoſe two learned Friers,A terrible blow. Bacon, and Bungey. The brazen head had ſpoke his laſt, for at this word the War broke out againe; one Cuffe from the Chaire upon the others Right Eare, made his head face quite about to the left ſhoulder, without hope, ever to ſee right forwards againe: This mortall chance engaged all the Company, who fell aboord, and battered one another without mercy: It ſeemd to raine Cloaks and Hatts,The maine battell. while Ruffs, bands, and Caſſocks, were diſmembred like the Frogs they had eaten, and flew up and downe as if they had been alive.

One there was amongſt the reſt, that had entertain'd the Time and Company, with a long diſcourſe in praiſe of Reebahs ſober Legacy to his Sons, whoſe very neer Kinſman he proved himſelfe to be, at the diſtance only of 2019. Generations, which he aſſur'd them was
all, and all the reaſon he knew, why that language of Hebrew ſeemd to him more naturall then this of his own mother Tongue: beeing as he offered to make it appeare, deſcended, ab originali, from the Iewes, and drawing his pedigree in ſtraight line, from Caiphas his Chamber keeper: Malchas told the wench that made fires in the high Prieſts Hall, the very fame, that made Peter deny his Maſter,He had Records to witneſſe it. which two he proteſted were Married together: This Gallant, by way of pure imitation would drink no Wine, but had ſo drownd himſelfe in a River of Ale, as getting into the middle of the roome, and ſtaring upon that wild crew, with Goggle-eyes, he ſtood there fixt, as if ſome body had turnd him into A Pillar of Malt, never to be removed, till the furious Chaire-man by the triall of Feet and Fiſts, quickly found him to be a dirty Moveable, and kickt him out of the roome.

Another that waited his opportunity, and ſeemd to pitty the Damſell becauſe he ſaw her in diſmay, led her meekly into a darke Cloſer in a corner of the roome, where clinging about her like jvy, he recoverd her by the virtue of frication, reclaimd her Haggard ſmiles, and made her feelingly merry: her abſence was quickly reſented by one, that loved her dearly, who ungrappling from a Veſſell that had boorded him, gave them Chaſe by the ſent, and found that Rabbin pluming his pullet inſtead of a Partridge, confounded with Jelouſie he bellowd out a rape, untwined their embraces, and flew upon his Rivall like a Cat A-mountaine, his roaring compelled the reſt to take notice of him, and being all in charity with the Nymph, which I beleeve was none of Dianaes, they took a minutes truce, and ran to her reſcue, where they diſcovered their Pigeon all to be ruffled, and the two enraged Combatants upon the Ground: clawing one another like a couple of Curry-combes.

I am not able to expreſſe the Chaire mans fury, whoſe peculiar darling ſhe was, his anger groand, and he foamd at the mouth, and grew ſo inſolent that he invaded freind and foe; at that inſtant high midnight appeared amongſt them an old man or a little fellow not ſo tall as himſelfe by the head, for he wanted one, I would faine have ſeene his face but could not for the reaſons aforeſaid, yet I think it was the Martyr Land, his hands arm'd with whips; ſcourged that Martiall Crew into admirable diſcipline, and it ſeemes, his blowes ſmarted, for they friskt up and downe the roome like Morris dancers,
The firſt that fled in this dreadfull viſion, was Angelica, who running downe ſtaires fell flat upon her face, at the bottome of them with her Traine, ſmock and all about her eares, and expoſing a paire of lovely buttocks, to the view, lay So as if ſhe had been dead by their diſpaires, two Doctors followed her at the heeles; one fell upon her right, the other upon her left hanch, which being white, pubble, and ſweet, they kiſt them cloſe with their cheeke, and fell faſt aſleepe, The Chaireman himſelfe came laſt, which flying from his tormentor, tript likewiſe upon the Virgin, and ran his noſe directly into her Moon-ſhine, Thoſe Heroes above terribly affrighted and tyrannically laſht, dropt downe ſuddenly into a Trance, and all was ſilent. The Miſtris had gotten her load and ſate below with eyes faſt lock'd, the Servants had likewiſe their ſhares, and preſented themſelves the true family of night, upon whom Morpheus had caſt the charme of a leaden ſlumber.

I, that was not with out my ſhiverings at this midnight ſpectacle, and not delighting in ſuch cruelty graſped the occaſion: opened my doore ſoftly and ſtept upon the ſtage, where I ſaw ſuch wonders acted: It was pav'd with cloakes, the candles, which ſignified that that ſpirit was not evil never went out, but gided me to ſeveral wines which well brew'd with ſugar, I powred downe plentifully. I ſeizd upon a light and ſaw how Ruffs, Coats, cloaks and beards lay ſtrowed up and downe, as thick as ruſhes: ſacriledge, I rememberd to be a ſinne, and therefore touched none of thoſe babiloniſh garments, leaſt I ſhould ſeeme to be guilty of it and rob their Church, but glided gently downe, and could hardly bridle my laughter, to ſee how thoſe Doctors lay like Church leeches, ſucking at the breech of the body politique, and certainly they hit upon the right veine, eſpecially he in the midſt that had the beſt ſhare by ods, for ſhe had evacuated as freely in his face, as if he had been newly giving her a Gliſter, which made the Grinning Chaireman look like a Gould-finder when diving into the bottome of his office he comes up again with his prey in his teeth, Jn a word, leaving theſe ſpirituall Fathers conſulting with the fleſh I unlock'd the ſtreet doore, ſhut it againe, went ſpeedily to my lodging, and as ſuddenly to bed, yet not till I had ſcribled down a few notes, as helps to facilitate the next dayes labour, and becauſe I reputed it an unpardonable Error to betray the leaſt dram of ſo deſerving a paſſage to unthankfull forgetfulneſſe.
